newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Brazil says court ruling won't delay sterling bond.
newsitem.headline: Brazil says court ruling won't delay sterling bond.

text.p: An Italian court ruling ordering the seizure of Brazilian assets, including a Eurolira bond issued in June, will not delay Brazil's upcoming sterling Eurobond, a Central Bank official said.
"Any claims or allegations that the bond will be delayed because of this is absolutely false," International Affairs Director Gustavo Franco told reporters at a news conference.
"We are waiting for the Bank of England's monetary policy meeting on Wednesday to see if interest rates will be raised. If they are then we would wait to issue the bond," Franco said.
An Italian court ruled on June 19 in favor of a group of companies who are suing the Brazilian government for failing to pay up after instructing them to buy coffee on its behalf.
The case has been in the courts for over six years.
Franco said he doubted whether the ruling by the Italian court was enforceable but added Brazilian government attorneys were looking into the matter.
He said all the proceeds from a 500 billion lira Eurobond issued on June 2, which was subject to the court order, had arrived in Brazil.
"There was no confiscation of any funds. All the money, $300 million, is in the Treasury," Franco said.

Brazilian newspapers on Monday reported that the Central Bank was considering postponing the issue of its 150-200 million 10-year sterling bond fearing another court might rule in favor of seizing the funds.
